data.name: Angular modules
data.description:
# ANGULAR MODULES INTRO
A very common concept in Angular is to use modules, so that the code is organised and can be reused easily accross different apps.
An example of this is: 

- We define our main app module: 
`angular.module('app', [])`

- We define another module with a service in it:
```
angular.module('profile', [])
.service('Users', function(){...})
```

- Now the `Users` service is only available in the profile module, so in order to use it in our app, we inject it like: 
`angular.module('app', ['profile'])`
Then we will be able to use it like this for example: 
```
angular.module('app', ['profile'])
.controller('appController', function(Users){
  Users...  
})
```

In order to define a new module you need to pass an array as a second argument: `angular.module('profile', [])` 

If the module is already defined and you want, for example, to build a controller, you wont pass such array in `angular.module('profile').controller('', function(){})`

Apart from the module definition, an angular app has to be bootstrapped. Usually this is done via the `ngApp` directive, but it can also be done with the `angular.bootstrap` function, which you will be defining as well. Normally it accept an element, modules, and config, but for this kata, just one module will be enough.

Please note that a module has to exist in order to be injected. For example, this should throw and error: 

`angular.module('app', ['profile'])`

and this should work fine: 

```
angular.module('app', ['profile']);
angular.module('profile', []);
```

# YOUR TASK

1. Define the module functionality so that it can define new modules and inject others.
2. Add the bootstrap functionality to build up the angular.modules array

Let's suppose that angular saves dependencies in a plain array. On the last example we'd have built:
```
angular.modules === ['app', 'profile'];
```

A more complex example will be: 
```
angular.module('app', ['profile', 'home']);
angular.module('profile', ['menu', 'forms']);
angular.module('home', ['menu']);
angular.module('menu', []);
angular.module('forms', []);
angular.bootstrap('app');
```

The result should be: 
`angular.modules === ['app', 'profile', 'home', 'menu', 'forms']`
